description: From Middle English wrek, from Anglo-Norman wrek, from Old Norse *wrek (Norwegian and Icelandic rek, Swedish vrak), from Proto-Germanic *wrekanƒÖ, whence also Old English wrecan (English wreak), Old High German rehhan, Old Saxon wrekan, Gothic êçÖêçÇêåπêå∫êå∞êåΩ (wrikan).

entries.meaning: Something or someone that has been ruined.
examples: He was an emotional wreck after the death of his wife.

entries.meaning: The remains of something that has been severely damaged or worn down.

definitionGroups.group: An event in which something is damaged through collision.

entries.meaning: (specifically, nautical) A shipwreck: an event in which a ship is heavily damaged or destroyed.
(law, not countable) Goods, etc. cast ashore by the sea after a shipwreck.
(ornithology) A large number of birds that have been brought to the ground, injured or dead, by extremely adverse weather.

verbs.description: wreck (third-person singular simple present wrecks, present participle wrecking, simple past and past participle wrecked)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To destroy violently; to cause severe damage to something, to a point where it no longer works, or is useless.
examples: He wrecked the car in a collision.
That adulterous hussy wrecked my marriage!

entries.meaning: (transitive, Australia) To dismantle wrecked vehicles or other objects, to reclaim any useful parts.
(transitive) To involve in a wreck; hence, to cause to suffer ruin; to balk of success, and bring disaster on.
(intransitive) To be involved in a wreck; to be damaged or destroyed.
examples: [‚Ä¶]  Mrs. Marleen Ketchum was not quite certain if the train wrecked or if the volcano blew its top. It took a moment before she was certain it had to be the passenger train.
